profileText: A Representative from Indiana; born in Richmond, Ind., June 18, 1808; attended Indiana University at Bloomington; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1828; engaged in banking; member of the State house of representatives 1832-1842 and served as speaker in 1840; elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-eighth, Twenty-ninth, and Thirtieth Congresses (March 4, 1843-March 3, 1849); chairman, Committee on Patents (Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Congresses); moved to California in 1849 and engaged in banking in Sacramento; member of the first State house of representatives 1851-1853; superintendent of Indian affairs of California 1855-1858; postmaster of San Francisco 1860-1864; died in Mendocino County, Calif., May 1, 1875; interment in Santa Rosa Cemetery, Santa Rosa, Calif.

1860, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John B. Weller to Jacob Thompson written on September 15, 1860. The letter recommends Mr. Poindexter as United States Marshal for the Southern District of California, and predicts that Breckenridge will carry that state. There are autograph notes from others, including Henley concurring.

researchRecord.description: A letter from Henley to George W. Manypenny written on April 14, 1855. This includes a transcript of an original report written by Henley while Superintendent of Indian Affairs for California on a survey of Indians in the Tejon and San Joaquin Valley areas.
